visibility_factors: falling and blowing snow 12 AM–4 AM

alert_summary.description: NWS expects 3–7" of snow in Ottawa County from Monday noon through Tuesday 7 AM, with hazardous travel impacting Monday PM and Tuesday AM commutes.
Heavier 6–12" band focused west/northwest (Muskegon/Oceana); Rockford is on the lighter advisory edge but close to the heavier snow axis.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary:
From a Michigan school-operations perspective, this looks more like a difficult commute than a slam-dunk snow day for Tuesday, December 2.

• Timing: The steadiest snow in your data runs late Monday evening through around 4:00 AM Tuesday (00:00–04:00 with moderate snow and ~3–4"/6–10 cm total between late Monday and early Tuesday). After 4 AM it shuts down to mist and clouds with no new accumulation during the typical bus window (6–9 AM).

• Amounts: Model output shows about 4.5 cm (≈1.8") of new snow listed for Tuesday, on top of Monday’s 4.9 cm (≈1.9"). Combined storm total in the Rockford area is on the order of 3–5"—solid but routine for West Michigan. The NWS advisory calling for 3–7" for Ottawa County aligns with that. This is below the threshold that usually forces closure in Rockford, especially when it’s spread over many hours rather than falling all at once.

• Temperatures: Roads remain below freezing all night (mid-20s °F), then hover 27–31 °F during the day. That favors snow staying somewhat powdery and plowable, with some compacted/slushy spots—no significant warming to cause a flash freeze scenario. All day and night temps stay at or below freezing, so there is no rain or mixed precip/ice signal, just snow and then mist/fog.

• Wind: Winds stay modest (generally 5–10 mph, gusts near 15–20 mph at times). That’s enough for some patchy blowing snow and reduced visibility while it’s still snowing, but not enough for true whiteout/blizzard conditions once rates taper. Wind is not the main hazard here.

• Visibility & roads: Visibility drops to ~1 mile during the overnight snow, then gradually improves to 2–6 miles with mist and low clouds by the commute hours. Because the accumulating snow ends before or around 4 AM and winds are moderate, road crews in Kent County should have several hours to plow/salt main routes before buses roll, though secondary/rural roads may stay snow-covered and slick for early drivers.

Snow-day implication for Rockford Public Schools (Tuesday 12/2):
- Probability of full closure: LOW to MODERATE (~25–35%).
- Probability of a delay: MODERATE (~35–45%), especially if overnight band over-performs or plowing lags on side roads.

In Michigan context, 3–5" with snow ending before the heart of the morning commute, modest winds, and no ice typically leads to school staying open, possibly with caution advisories or at most a 1–2 hour delay rather than a full snow day. The nearby Winter Storm Warning to the west is notable, but Rockford’s forecast and your advisory-level totals point to tough but manageable winter driving rather than a likely shutdown.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Overnight advisory-level snow (3–7" forecast for nearby Ottawa County) tapering toward daybreak with light additional accumulation, temps in the 20s, winds under 15 mph, and improving visibilities by the start of the school day.

6–10" ‘winter storm watch/warning’ corridors primarily west (Muskegon/Oceana coastal band) with inland Rockford on the fringe getting several inches but not the full lake-effect maxima; main hazardous travel window centered Monday evening and early overnight, not during the school commute itself.

First sizable early-December event with advisory-level totals and some blowing snow, but no extreme cold (wind chills generally in the teens, well above -15°F) and no ice; roads slick but plowable with normal overnight road maintenance.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: For early December in west-central Lower Michigan (Rockford/Grand Rapids corridor), it is climatologically normal to see the first or second accumulating lake-effect/synoptic snow event by now. Daytime highs around 30°F and lows in the 20s are common, and 1–4" snowfalls with locally higher lake-effect bands occur several times each December. School closures around this date historically correlate more with intense, poorly timed lake-effect bands, blizzard-like visibility, or flash freezing than with routine 3–7" advisory events.
unusual_factors: NWS products show a Winter Storm Warning/Watch focused on Muskegon/Oceana and a Winter Weather Advisory for Ottawa/Newaygo, indicating the heaviest 6–12" band is expected mainly west and northwest of Rockford rather than squarely overhead.

The hourly forecast for Rockford itself shows the bulk of steady ‘moderate snow’ occurring late Monday evening into the very early hours of Tuesday (roughly 8 PM–4 AM), with snow intensity dropping to mist and then no new accumulation by the 5–8 AM school commute window.
Winds remain modest (generally under 15 mph, gusts under ~20 mph) so there is not a strong signal for whiteout/blizzard conditions inland by Tuesday morning.

local_microclimates: Rockford sits inland from the Lake Michigan shore; in these synoptic-plus-lake-effect events, the most intense, persistent bands often focus closer to the lakeshore (Muskegon/Oceana) with somewhat reduced totals as you move inland toward Kent County.

Terrain around Rockford has rolling hills and river valleys that can hold cold air and localized fog/mist, but it does not typically amplify snowfall to the same degree as immediate lakeshore convergence zones.
infrastructure_considerations: West Michigan districts (including Rockford) are accustomed to handling 3–7" overnight snowfalls; local road commissions usually have main routes treated or plowed before the morning commute when the heaviest snow ends by pre-dawn.
Michigan districts rarely close for snow alone unless amounts exceed roughly 8–10" with poor timing (still falling hard during bus runs) or are accompanied by strong winds causing whiteouts.
No signal for ice, mixed precipitation, or extreme cold means buses and buildings can operate normally, assuming standard plowing and salting.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modest elevation above Grand River level can lead to slightly colder overnight lows and patchy fog/mist, but the forecast wind speeds and temperatures do not indicate a significant elevation-driven enhancement of hazardous conditions beyond normal slick roads.

history.confidence_assessment: Taking the forecast literally, Rockford sees a solid but manageable early-season snow event: several inches of snow mainly from Monday afternoon through early Tuesday pre-dawn, then tapering to mist and clouds with temps in the mid‑20s to low‑30s and light winds for the Tuesday, December 2 school day. Historically for this part of Michigan, that pattern more often results in school operating on time, with some localized slick spots and slower travel, rather than a full snow day. Because advisory and warning areas are focused a bit west of Rockford and the heaviest snow is front-loaded before the commute, the historical analogs suggest a relatively low closure probability and a somewhat higher chance of just messy but passable conditions. Overall confidence in this assessment is medium: the main uncertainty is whether any persistent, stronger lake-effect band lingers into the 4–7 AM window; if that occurred and local totals pushed toward the upper end (near or above 8" with very low visibility exactly at bus time), closure likelihood would rise, but current guidance and alerts lean more toward marginal-to-moderate impact rather than a classic Michigan snow day trigger for Rockford specifically.

safety_recommendations: Expect 3–7+ inches of total snow in the broader advisory area, with heaviest falling Monday afternoon through the overnight hours into early Tuesday (before ~5 AM).
Temperatures remain below freezing (mid 20s–near 30°F) through the event, so most snow will stick and compact on untreated surfaces, particularly neighborhood/bus-route side streets and parking lots.

Primary roads and highways in West Michigan are likely to be plowed and treated repeatedly overnight; by 6–8 AM Tuesday they should be passable but slushy, with localized slick spots and some residual snowpack in turn lanes and shoulders.
Secondary roads and subdivision streets may still have packed snow and ruts for the Tuesday morning commute, especially where bands of heavier snow set up Monday evening.

Visibility issues are greatest Monday evening and overnight during moderate snow (including around midnight–4 AM); by 6–8 AM Tuesday, snowfall has tapered to mist/low clouds with visibility generally improving, though patchy fog/mist could linger.
Bridges, overpasses, and untreated hills/intersections will be high-risk for black ice and compacted snow Tuesday morning due to subfreezing temps and prior snowfall.

Walking conditions for students will be slick: expect snow- and ice-covered sidewalks, driveway aprons, and school walkways early Tuesday; schools should allow extra time for clearing and salting sidewalks and entrances.

Winds are relatively light (generally under 15 mph), so blowing/drifting and whiteout risk are limited compared to classic lake-effect blizzard setups, but some drifting in open rural areas is still possible.

Given Michigan’s robust plow operations and the tapering of snow before the main 6–8 AM commute, conditions favor a regular or possibly short delay rather than a full snow day, unless local snowfall totals significantly exceed forecast or plowing lags in specific neighborhoods.

Monitor updated NWS advisories overnight; if bands stall and deposits approach the high end of warning criteria near Rockford’s travel corridors, consider early-morning spot checks on key bus routes before finalizing any closure decision.

local_news.source: Yahoo News / MLive-style school closing forecast
local_news.headline: School closing prediction for Monday–Tuesday: Grand Rapids/Rockford area unlikely to see widespread closures
local_news.summary: A regional school closing prediction for West Michigan indicates that the best chance for school closings is along the lakeshore in western Allegan and northern Van Buren counties, where heavy lake-effect snow is expected. The Grand Rapids metro area (including Rockford and Kent County suburbs) is specifically described as likely to remain outside the heaviest snow bands, with snow ‘very unlikely to cause school closings.’ This points to relatively low closure odds for Rockford-area schools for Tuesday, Dec. 2, 2025, based on current forecast trends.

local_news.source: National Weather Service / Manistee News Advocate (regional context)
local_news.headline: Winter storm alerts Dec. 1–2 mainly north and along the lakeshore
local_news.summary: Winter weather advisories and a winter storm warning are in effect Dec. 1–2 for counties along the Lake Michigan shoreline (Manistee, Benzie, Mason). Hazardous travel with heavy lake-effect snow and reduced visibility is expected there from Monday afternoon into Tuesday morning. While this highlights dangerous travel elsewhere in West Michigan, Kent County (Grand Rapids/Rockford) is not the primary target of these warnings, suggesting that the worst impacts are displaced to the north and northwest of Rockford.

local_news.source: Forest Hills Public Schools (inclement weather info)
local_news.headline: Forest Hills PS: How we communicate school closings & delays
local_news.summary: Forest Hills Public Schools (neighboring Rockford) outlines that closing/delay decisions are communicated via SchoolMessenger, the district homepage, their Facebook page, and local media. No special alerts, banners, or news posts about a closure or delay for Tuesday, Dec. 2, 2025, are visible as of the latest check, implying they have not yet announced any disruption for that date.

official_announcements: Rockford Public Schools (Rockford, MI – Kent County) official website and social channels show no posted announcement of a closure, delay, or early dismissal for Tuesday, Dec. 2, 2025, as of the latest scan. Any decision appears not yet communicated publicly and would likely follow their standard early-morning-of process via robocall/text, website, and local media if conditions worsen overnight.

Neighboring district Forest Hills Public Schools (FHPS) has only general school-closings guidance posted; there are no news posts, home-page alerts, or social-media notices indicating a closure or delay for Tuesday, Dec. 2, 2025.

Cedar Springs, Sparta, Lowell, Greenville, and Kent ISD: no closure announcements or advance cancellation notices for Tuesday, Dec. 2, 2025, were found on district homepages or recent social feeds; they appear to be in normal-operations planning mode at this time.

Local TV closing lists (WOOD TV8, WZZM 13, FOX 17) do not yet show broad preemptive closure headlines for Kent County schools for the Tuesday morning commute; any eventual closures would likely appear on those outlets closer to Tuesday morning if conditions degrade.
neighboring_district_closures: No neighboring Kent County districts (Forest Hills, Cedar Springs, Sparta, Lowell, Greenville, Kent ISD) are currently reporting confirmed closures or delays for Tuesday, Dec. 2, 2025, based on their official websites and recent public posts.

Regional lake-effect hotspots to the southwest and along the lakeshore (e.g., western Allegan and northern Van Buren counties) are highlighted in forecasts as most likely to see school closures due to heavier snow bands; this pattern does not directly implicate Rockford or the immediate Kent County ring of districts at this time.

reported_road_conditions: As of late Monday, Dec. 1, 2025, Kent County Road Commission and MDOT feeds indicate winter-weather operations (salting/plowing) are ongoing regionally, but there are no widespread reports of impassable roads or countywide travel advisories specifically centered on Rockford.

Forecast discussions emphasize more significant lake-effect bands closer to the lakeshore and farther south/southwest, with the Grand Rapids/Rockford corridor expected to see lighter snow and more manageable travel, barring any unexpected band shifts overnight.
local_event_cancellations: No major Rockford Public Schools events or evening activities for Monday night into Tuesday have been widely publicized as canceled due to weather in local media or on major social feeds checked.
Regional coverage notes winter-weather-related schedule changes in other parts of the Midwest, but nothing specifically targeting Rockford, MI, for Dec. 2, 2025.

news.key_findings_summary:
For Tuesday, Dec. 2, 2025, there are currently no official Rockford Public Schools (Rockford, MI) announcements of a closure, delay, or early dismissal. Neighboring Kent County districts (Forest Hills, Cedar Springs, Sparta, Lowell, Greenville, Kent ISD) likewise show no pre-announced closures or delays.

Regional forecast intel and a published school-closing prediction piece indicate that the highest odds of school closures from this lake-effect event are along the Lake Michigan shoreline and in western Allegan/northern Van Buren counties, not in the Grand Rapids/Rockford corridor. This suggests lower—but not zero—closure likelihood for Rockford on Tuesday morning, assuming forecasts verify.

Road and power information show routine winter operations without large-scale outages or emergency travel declarations focused on Rockford. Community/social chatter visible in public sources leans more toward general weather watching than a strong consensus that “schools will definitely be closed,” so sentiment is best characterized as uncertain rather than strongly expecting closure.

Net read: As of Monday night, Dec. 1, 2025, the available signals point toward Rockford Public Schools and neighboring districts planning for normal operations on Tuesday, Dec. 2, with the usual caveat that a final decision could still be made early Tuesday morning if localized bands intensify or road conditions deteriorate more than currently forecast.

primary_factors: Total storm snow for Rockford around 3–5", below typical Michigan closure thresholds
Heaviest snow ends by ~4–5 AM with no new accumulation during main bus window
Temperatures stay below freezing but with no rain, glazing, or mixed precip signal (no classic ice event)
Winds modest (generally <15 mph), so no blizzard/whiteout conditions for the commute
Safety expert characterizes commute as moderate risk with plowed but slick roads, not widespread impassable conditions
Historical analogs for similar overnight advisory events show ~20–30% closure rates, favoring school staying open
News/community intel: no neighboring Kent County districts have announced closures or delays; regional closing forecasts explicitly say GR/Rockford snow is unlikely to cause closings
Regional winter storm warning focus is west/northwest (lakeshore), with Rockford on the lighter advisory fringe
final.decision_rationale:
1. Expert agreement vs. disagreement
- AGREEMENTS:
  • All four inputs agree Rockford is on the lighter/advisory edge of a stronger storm focused west and northwest (Muskegon/Oceana, lakeshore counties).
  • Expected storm total near Rockford is in the 3–5" range, not 8"+.
  • Steadier accumulating snow peaks Monday evening through very early Tuesday (~midnight–4/5 AM), then shuts off or becomes non-accumulating mist/fog by the 6–8 AM commute.
  • Winds are modest; no blizzard or whiteout signal inland by bus time.
  • Roads will be slick but largely plowed on primaries by morning; secondaries and parking lots will be messy but not generally impassable.
  • No rain or mixed precip flag in the meteorological or historical data; temps stay in the 20s–near 30°F.
  • Historically and operationally in Michigan, this setup more often leads to school operating on time (or with a possible delay) than a full closure.
  • News intel and regional closing forecasts explicitly state that the Grand Rapids/Rockford corridor is unlikely to see widespread school closings, with closures more likely closer to the lakeshore.

- DISAGREEMENTS / TENSIONS:
  • Safety assessment lists ice_formation_risk as "high" due to subfreezing temps and compacted snow on untreated surfaces, while meteorology shows no pure ice event (no freezing rain, no warm-up/flash-freeze). This is a difference in wording: the safety expert is highlighting black-ice patches on bridges/side streets, not a region-wide glazing storm.
  • Meteorologist gives full-closure probability ~25–35% with delay odds 35–45%. Historical data for similar patterns shows a 20–30% closure rate. News intel implies even lower odds because forecasts and media are signaling that GR/Rockford are outside the main closure zone.
  • Community sentiment is described as uncertain, not strongly convinced of closure; there is no strong crowd expectation to push probabilities upward.

2. Plow timing math
- Worst conditions end time from safety analyst: ~05:00 EST Tuesday.
- Typical first bus / start-of-operations window: ~6:00–7:40 AM.
- That gives roughly 1–2.5 hours of no new accumulation before the earliest buses, and closer to 2–3+ hours before the final arrivals.
- Overnight crews in Kent County are experienced with exactly this scenario. With 3–5" total and snow ending before the commute, primaries and major bus routes are very likely to be plowed/salted at least once, leaving them slushy but passable. Secondary roads and parking lots will be the weak link but still generally navigable with caution.
- This timing favors either normal operations or, at most, a short delay if plows lag in specific neighborhoods—consistent with both the meteorologist and safety analyst.

3. Ice assessment
- Meteorology: all precip is snow; temps remain at or below freezing with no warm layer aloft and no above-freezing surface temps to create melt-refreeze or freezing rain. No explicit ice storm or mixed-precip signature.
- Safety: "high" ice formation risk is due to:
  • Subfreezing pavement temperatures.
  • Packed snow leading to polished/icy spots, especially on bridges/overpasses, hills, and untreated side streets.
  • This is localized black ice risk, not a region-wide glaze.
- Given the Michigan thresholds, this does NOT qualify as an "ice event" that automatically pushes into the 60–85% closure band. It is standard winter slickness that districts are accustomed to managing, not a transformational hazard like a freezing rain storm.

4. Neighboring district status
- News intelligence is clear:
  • Rockford Public Schools: no pre-announced closure or delay.
  • Neighboring districts (Forest Hills, Cedar Springs, Sparta, Lowell, Greenville, Kent ISD): no closure/delay announcements; all appear to be planning normal operations.
  • TV closing lists are not flagging Kent County as an area of expected widespread closures.
- This means:
  • 0 neighboring districts are confirmed closed.
  • No +15–20% adjustment from neighboring-district closures.
  • Media forecasting pieces specifically say the GR/Rockford area snow is “very unlikely to cause school closings.” That is a strong negative signal for closures.

5. Base probability using Michigan thresholds
- Expected snow in Rockford: ~3–5" total (split between Monday and early Tuesday), with about 1.8" new in the late-night period. That is near the low end of the 4–6" band, not a storm-total 8"+ event.
- Timing: heaviest snow overnight, tapering before the core bus window.
- No major wind, no pure ice, no blizzard conditions.
- Using the provided Michigan thresholds:
  • <4" → 5–15%.
  • 4–6" → 15–35%.
  • We are around the boundary of those two, but operationally closer to a routine advisory event than a high-impact one.

6. Weighting the four expert domains
- Meteorology (35% weight):
  • Characterizes this as a “difficult commute” but not a slam-dunk snow day.
  • Gives full-closure probability 25–35%.
  • I anchor the meteorological contribution near 30%.

- Safety (25% weight):
  • Labels risk as moderate, with roads slick but passable and specific concern for bridges, secondaries, and walking conditions.
  • States conditions favor regular or possibly short delay rather than a full snow day.
  • I interpret this as roughly 20–30% closure odds; I center safety contribution around 25%.

- History (20% weight):
  • Analog patterns show 20–30% closure rates.
  • Seasonal adjustment actually nudges probability slightly down because such events are common and usually handled without closures.
  • I set the historical contribution at ~22%.

- News Intelligence (20% weight, secret weapon):
  • Forecast articles explicitly say closures are unlikely for the GR/Rockford corridor.
  • No neighboring district closures, no strong community expectation of a snow day.
  • This should pull probabilities down within the threshold band, not up.
  • I set the news-intel contribution at ~10–15%; I’ll use 12% as a working value.

Weighted blend (approximate):
- Meteorology: 0.35 × 30% ≈ 10.5
- Safety: 0.25 × 25% ≈ 6.25
- History: 0.20 × 22% ≈ 4.4
- News intel: 0.20 × 12% ≈ 2.4
- Sum ≈ 23.5%.

Given the explicit Michigan threshold guidance (4–6" → 15–35%) and the strong negative signal from news intel and neighbors (no closings expected here), I round slightly downward for calibration, to 22%.

7. Why not higher?
- We do NOT have:
  • 8"+ focused directly on Rockford.
  • Ongoing heavy snow during the entire bus window.
  • Blowing/drifting with whiteouts.
  • A true ice storm.
  • Multiple neighboring districts already announcing closures.
- Instead, we have:
  • Advisory-level totals, mainly overnight.
  • Several plow hours before buses.
  • Media and forecast messaging that specifically downplays closure odds in this corridor.

8. What would make this prediction wrong?
- Upside closure risk (our 22% is too low) if:
  • A persistent lake-effect band parks over Rockford/Kent County through 4–8 AM, pushing local totals near or above ~8" right at commute time.
  • Plowing or salting underperforms (equipment issues, staffing, band placement) so that secondaries and hills are much worse than usual for a 3–5" event.
  • An unmodeled sleet/freezing-drizzle component briefly adds a thin glaze on top of the snow near dawn (not currently indicated).

- Downside risk (our 22% is too high) if:
  • The heavier bands stay entirely west/northwest, and Rockford verifies closer to 2–3" total with very light overnight rates.
  • Road crews clear everything efficiently and early, leaving only minor slick spots.

Given all four expert domains and the Michigan context, a 22% closure probability reflects a low but nontrivial chance that something over-performs (band stalls, plows lag) but keeps us well out of the midrange, in line with both history and current real-time signals.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Snow bands underperform inland; Rockford only receives around 2–3" total with cleanly plowed roads by 6 AM, visibility good, and only routine slick spots.
alternative_scenarios.impact: Schools run on time with normal winter cautions; closure probability would effectively be near 5–10%.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Forecast verifies as expected: 3–5" total with snow ending by ~4–5 AM; primaries mostly clear, secondaries and lots slick but navigable.
alternative_scenarios.impact: Most likely outcome; schools open on time, with some slower routes and potentially isolated bus/parent delays but no system-wide closure.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Lake-effect band lingers or shifts over Rockford toward morning, pushing local totals closer to 6–8" with poorer visibility and slower plow progress on side roads.
alternative_scenarios.impact: Morning commute becomes more hazardous; school might consider a 2-hour delay or, if plows are clearly behind and multiple neighboring districts close, a full closure becomes plausible (this is the ~22% bucket).

for_schools: Plan for normal operations on Tuesday, Dec. 2, while remaining ready to reassess around 4:30–5:30 AM based on actual band placement and road reports.
Coordinate with Kent County Road Commission overnight to confirm expected plow coverage on primary bus routes by 6 AM, and ask specifically about problem hills, bridges, and rural segments.

Have building and grounds crews scheduled early to clear and salt parking lots, sidewalks, and entrances; prioritize bus loops and parent drop-off zones where compacted snow and black ice are most likely.
Prepare internal contingency messaging for a possible short delay if early-morning spot checks reveal worse-than-forecast conditions on secondaries or subdivision routes.
Advise staff and families in advance (even if school is expected to be open) that roads and walkways will be slick; encourage allowing extra travel time and careful loading/unloading at bus stops.
for_residents: Expect plowed but slick conditions Tuesday morning; plan to leave extra time for the commute and reduce speeds on side streets, hills, and bridges.
Use winter tires if available and ensure windshield washer fluid and wipers are in good condition; visibility may be reduced at times by lingering mist/fog.
Be cautious walking on sidewalks, driveways, and parking lots; assume untreated surfaces may have black ice or packed snow, especially early.
If you live on a rural or less-prioritized road, consider the possibility that it will remain snow-covered or rutted through the early morning even if main roads are mostly clear.
Monitor official school messages, local TV/radio, or district websites early Tuesday morning for any last-minute delay or closure announcements in case overnight conditions change.
for_authorities: Continue standard overnight plowing and salting operations, emphasizing primary roads and known bus corridors between roughly midnight and 5 AM.
Pay particular attention to bridges, overpasses, and known trouble intersections where high ice risk is flagged, even without a freezing-rain signal.
Coordinate with school transportation departments to identify priority routes for early-morning checks (rural hills, shaded curves, subdivision chokepoints).

Have communication lines ready between road agencies, law enforcement, and school superintendents between about 4:30 and 6:00 AM to share real-time road-condition updates before any final school-closure decisions.
Monitor radar for any persistent or retrenching lake-effect bands toward Rockford/Kent County in the 2–6 AM window; be prepared to escalate plow efforts if a band stalls over key corridors.

alert.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 30 at 10:25PM EST until December 2 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations between 6 and
10 inches possible.

* WHERE...Ottawa, Muskegon, and Oceana Counties.

* WHEN...From Monday afternoon through Tuesday morning.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibilities may drop below 1/4
mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are
possible and may make travel treacherous and potentially
life-threatening.
alert.instruction:
Monitor the latest forecasts for updates on this situation.

If travel is necessary, drive with caution and expect snow covered
roads and slippery conditions.
